diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, causing pain, swelling, and potentially leading to joint deformity.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears, often leading to dry mouth and eyes, and can cause joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to numerous symptoms including ulcers, arthritis, and skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, leading to symptoms like swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), fatigue, and fever.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), leading to a severely weakened immune system and can cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands, causing granulomas and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Reactive arthritis
diagnoses.description: A condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, leading to joint pain, swelling, and occasionally, skin problems like ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium, spread by tick bites. Symptoms can include erythema migrans, fever, headache, and muscle and joint aches.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that primarily affects the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses: Lymphatic Metastasis from unknown primary tumor

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disorder can manifest with xerosis (dry skin) and blepharospasm (involuntary eyelid closure) due to its impact on moisture-producing glands.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.reason: As a common cause of hyperthyroidism, Graves' disease can indirectly contribute to eye-related symptoms (through thyroid eye disease) and could exacerbate osteoporosis due to the effects of excess thyroid hormone on bone density.

diagnoses.name: Hypoparathyroidism
diagnoses.reason: While not directly causing all the listed symptoms, its impact on calcium and phosphate balance can lead to cataracts (which might be confused with or contribute to blepharospasm) and osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.reason: Vitamin D is crucial for bone health and its deficiency can lead to osteoporosis. It might not directly cause xerosis or blepharospasm but can contribute to overall poor health.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune condition can have systemic effects including xerosis and, through secondary Sjögren's syndrome, can contribute to blepharospasm. It can also accelerate the development of osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms including those affecting the skin and eyes, and it can indirectly affect bone health.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Eye Disease
diagnoses.reason: Associated with hyperthyroidism/Graves' Disease, this can cause eye symptoms but doesn't directly account for all listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Osteoporosis
diagnoses.reason: Conditions like hyperthyroidism can lead to secondary osteoporosis, highlighting the interconnection between some of the listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, potentially indicated by severe xerosis, but less directly related to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Pneumococcal Pneumonia
diagnoses.reason: While pneumonia itself is a diagnosis, in the presence of osteoporosis and potential immunocompromise (e.g., from rheumatoid arthritis or steroid use for another condition), the risk and severity may increase.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A common anxiety disorder characterized by uncontrollable worrying, nervousness, and tension.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition where open sores develop on the inner lining of the stomach and the upper portion of the small intestine.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which breathing stops and starts repeatedly during sleep due to throat muscles intermittently relaxing and blocking the airway.

diagnoses.name: Kounis Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare condition involving acute coronary syndromes triggered by an allergic or hypersensitivity reaction.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A disorder thought to be triggered by exposure to low levels of chemicals in the environment. Symptoms include headaches, fatigue, and sore throat, among others, and might relate to the physical sensitivities described.

diagnoses.name: Functional Gastrointestinal Disorder
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders categorized by persistent stomach and bowel-related symptoms without a clear physical cause, which might explain ulcers if they are stress-related.

diagnoses.name: Panic Disorder
diagnoses.description: A type of anxiety disorder characterized by sudden and repeated attacks of fear that last for several minutes or longer.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: Also known as chronic hives, a condition where hives or welts appear on the skin, possibly linked to allergies and related to Kounis syndrome in allergy-induced scenarios.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, fatigue, and potentially hypersensitivity to pain, correlating with physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder that affects the lungs, caused by inhaling certain dusts (allergens) to which you are allergic, potentially related to broader physical sensitivities.

diagnoses: Vitamin B12 Deficiency or Folate Deficiency
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which could indirectly lead to urinary tract infections due to overall decrease in body secretions.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including urinary tract infections, due to high sugar levels fostering bacterial growth, and episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that impairs kidney function, leading to a build-up of waste products in the body, which can cause symptoms such as urinary tract infections and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, potentially causing episodic weakness, urinary tract infections (due to bladder dysfunction), and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by variable weakness of voluntary muscles, which might be misinterpreted or associated with episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can have systemic effects including dry eyes (secondary Sjögren's syndrome), and increased susceptibility to infections like bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including causing dry eyes, hypersensitivity reactions, and increasing susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid does not produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to dry eyes, general weakness, and potentially increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe, often leading to bronchitis episodes.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition in which stomach acid comes up into the esophagus, which doesn't directly correlate with the listed symptoms but can indirectly affect overall health and exacerbate or contribute to conditions like bronchitis due to aspiration.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Blepharospasm as part of Benign Essential Blepharospasm or as a secondary symptom of another condition

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Chemical poisoning (e.g., histamine poisoning from spoiled fish)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, facial drooping, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. The inflammation may be caused by infection with viruses, bacteria, or other microorganisms. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can cause symptoms such as headache, fever, vomiting, and changes in mental status.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms vary widely depending on the tumor's size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a powerful headache that often happens with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. It can last hours or days.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the whole body.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. The cause is usually a viral infection, but bacteria can also cause it. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, a stiff neck, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding into the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane, called the subarachnoid space. The primary symptom is a sudden, severe headache. It can be a life-threatening condition requiring immediate medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms of a TIA are like other stroke symptoms but do not last as long.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as dysarthria, numbness, and visual disturbances like scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It can lead to symptoms such as numbness, weakness, balance issues, and speech difficulties like dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves visual disturbances, including scintillation, along with or followed by migraine headaches. Other symptoms can include numbness and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke, such as dysarthria, numbness, and visual problems like scintillation. TIAs usually last only a few minutes and don't cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can affect brain function depending on their location and size, potentially causing dysarthria, numbness, and visual symptoms such as scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: ALS is a type of motor neuron disease that causes the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles. Early symptoms can include speech difficulties like dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some types of focal seizures may present with symptoms like dysarthria, numbness, or visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to symptoms including weakness and tingling in the extremities, which can progress to numbness and paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A common complication of diabetes involving damage to the nerves due to high blood sugar levels. Symptoms can include numbness, tingling, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is a bacterial infection you get from the bite of an infected tick. Early symptoms may include a rash, fever, headaches, and fatigue, while later stages can involve neurological symptoms such as facial palsy and neuropathy, inducing numbness.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Microscopic Polyangiitis, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Chronic Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus (Discoid Lupus Erythematosus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Viral Infections (such as HIV, Hepatitis C)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including skin, joints, kidneys (proteinuria), and neurological system (cranial neuropathy). Oral ulcers are also a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash, dermatomyositis can also manifest with systemic features like arthropathy. Kidney involvement can lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Bullous Pemphigoid
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune skin condition causes large, fluid-filled blisters (bullous rash). It can be associated with other autoimmune disorders that cause the remaining symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms often include oral ulcers, skin rashes, and can involve the eyes (neuropathy), joints, and possibly kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders causes vessel inflammation, affecting many systems. It can lead to skin rashes, kidney damage (proteinuria), oral ulcers, and nerve issues (cranial neuropathy).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This disease features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders — lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including arthritis, muscle weakness, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder primarily affecting the glands that produce tears and saliva but can also cause joint pain (arthropathy) and kidney dysfunction (proteinuria).

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, often in reaction to a medication or infection. It can lead to severe skin rashes (bullous rash) and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder causes blistering and erosion of the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing joint inflammation and pain (arthropathy), RA can also have systemic effects including skin rashes, renal involvement (proteinuria), and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses: COVID-19 (especially with long-COVID manifestations or severe infection)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)
Malignant Hematologic Disorders (e.g., lymphoma or leukemia)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
